content.question: The beam of monochromatic light is replaced with a beam of light that consists of two different wavelengths, one with wavelength <math alttext="three fourths lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mi>λ</mi></math> and one with wavelength <math alttext="four thirds lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>λ</mi></math>. Will the interference pattern on the screen be the same as the pattern with monochromatic light? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes , because the interference pattern does not depend on wavelength
Yes, because the average wavelength is still <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>
No, because there will be two superimposed interference patterns, each with different distances between maxima
No, because the light with different wavelengths will cancel each other and there will be no interference pattern

content.answer: No, because there will be two superimposed interference patterns, each with different distances between maxima
